awd_titl_txt: CAS: Glyonic Liquids: Sugar-Based Ionic Liquids and Deep Eutectic Solvents from Sustainable Sources for Electrochemical Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professors Jeanne E. Pemberton and Steve D. Schwartz of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at the University of Arizona are developing a new class of conductive liquids to be used in batteries.  These new materials, glyonic liquids, are made from biomass (e.g., sugars) and are biodegradable and nontoxic. The goal of this research is to optimize the conductive properties of these materials by molecular design and tp explore their applications as green, renewable conductive electrolytes in devices used for sensing and energy conversion and storage. The project lies at the interface of organic, physical  and materials chemistry.  This effort will also support the development of new intellectual property and educational initiatives at the graduate, undergraduate and K-12 science levels, with a particular emphasis on impacting members of underrepresented groups who are a large demographic base in southern Arizona. Outreach activities include the development of a workshop for in-service secondary science teachers on green chemistry and sustainability.

Glyonic liquids are a new type of protic ionic liquid structurally based on a rhamnolipid platform as the anion can be paired with a variety of cations. These materials have demonstrated intriguing conductive properties that might make them excellent choices for use in electrochemical devices. Toward that end, this effort involves three specific objectives: 1) synthesis and property tuning of glyonic liquids based on the rhamnolipid structural motif through exploitation of synthetic handles that facilitate retention of these materials in the liquid state at or near room temperature; 2) exploration of electrochemical applications of these glyonic liquids; and 3) computational studies on glyonic liquids to define inter/intramolecular interactions and structure at the nano- and meso-scales as a function of temperature.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report:

CAS: Glyonic Liquids: Sugar-Based Ionic Liquids and Deep Eutectic Solvents from Sustainable Sources for Electrochemical Applications

 

Jeanne E. Pemberton, PI

Steven D. Schwartz, Co-PI 

University of Arizona

 

Ionic liquids are salts that remain in the liquid state at or close to room temperature with considerably lower viscosities than their predecessor molten salts. As such, ionic liquids have become attractive as sustainable, green solvents to replace conventional volatile organic solvents, with an annual commercial market over $3B. Ionic liquids have the beneficial characteristics of electrical conductivity, non-flammability, thermal and electrochemical stability, and many have negligible vapor pressure. Traditionally, these materials are composed of large organic cations with simple inorganic and organic anions, both of which can be chemically tuned to tailor properties. One broad class of ionic liquids are protic ionic liquids formed by proton transfer from a Brønsted acid to a Brønsted base. Cations in protic ionic liquids commonly come from amine and imidazole-based molecules. Common anions are simple inorganic or organic anions such as carboxylates, nitrates, sulfonates, phosphates and borates, with more exotic anions less frequently reported. Few protic ionic liquids have been reported from renewable sources. This effort introduced  a whole new class of protic ionic liquids in which the anions are based on sugar-containing biosurfactants called monorhamnolipids; these biosurfactants are efficiently produced by microorganisms in biofermentation processes that have been successfully scaled by commercial enterprises. The anion forms of these monorhamnolipids are combined with simple amine cations to create this new class of materials that we have termed glyonic liquids. Significant advantages accrue to these glyonic liquids, including that they are very inexpensive compared with most other ionic liquid systems. In addition, by thoughtful choice of cation, glyonic liquids can be produced that are fully renewably resourced and fully biocompatible and biodegradable. 

During this grant award, we undertook a comprehensive effort to understand the physicochemical properties of these unique materials and explore their potential for use in electrochemical systems and carbon dioxide harvesting applications. Specifically, for a series of glyonic liquids made from monorhamnolipid anions with 6 different simple amine cations, we characterized the densities, the conductivity properties, the rheological properties, and the carbon dioxide absorption properties. These experimental efforts were supported by a computational effort involving molecular dynamics simulations that provided critical insight into molecular structure and dynamics in these systems. Strong evidence for superionic conductivity in these glyonic liquids under certain conditions was obtained. These materials have strong potential for real application in two important technology areas: 1) as proton transport membranes in electrochemical devices to replace the most commonly used proton transport membrane material, Nafion, which is highly fluorinated and therefore, a “forever chemical”, and 2) carbon dioxide and other gas harvesting applications.

In addition to the intellectual merit of the research activities, this work also had significant broader impacts. In addition to introducing a whole new and novel class of protic ionic liquids, our efforts also had significant impact on student education and training with 2 postdoctoral researchers, 7 graduate students, and 2 undergraduate students involved in the research. One doctoral student and three master’s degree students completed their degrees during this grant award. Significant intellectual property was developed through this research resulting in the submission of three patent applications during the award period. Finally, a new in-service secondary chemistry teacher course entitled “Green Chemistry and Living in the Desert” was developed and offered to local southern Arizona secondary teachers at the University of Arizona during the grant period for University credit. This course is designed to give secondary chemistry teachers readily usable materials for their classes that provide essential chemistry concepts and ideas using meaningful, familiar topics connected to green chemistry and sustainability.  

 


Last Modified: 08/01/2024
Modified by: Jeanne E Pemberton
